climbs.name: 3D
climbs.fa: Martin Bigras, Stéphane Cantin, Patrick Wait, 1996

content.description:
Direct start to Bi-Centenaire.

Below the roof, left of the right facing dihedral.
Mixed, keep a few cams handy.

5 kilomètres is an old aid climb that has, in the recent years, been freed.

The original line showed in Pierre Cornellier's guidebook shows a line that start left of the huge flakes where Le Temple du Soleil starts as well. Apparently, no body has yet linked free into Le Temple du Soleil which in my own opinion is the logical finish!

Bolts seem to be well spaced!

Start on bolts to the left of the giant flake shared with Le Temple du Soleil. 
Bolts

The very small route that people use to warm up, the start remains intriguing before joining easier terrain. Impossible to miss the 4 bolts just on the right of the crack. La très petite ligne que les gens utilisé pour se réchauffer, le départ reste intriguant avant de rejoindre du terrain plus facile. Impossible à manquer les 4 plaquettes juste à droite de la fissure. Bolted
Bolted rap anchor.

P1, 5.10 
 Large vertical crack, often wet, followed by a small horizontal crack then up to the Vire a Bicyclette. 
 P2, 5.10+ 
 Starts in Le Grand Bill and traverses right in a small dihedral, same exit as Le Grand Bill. 
  
 Possibility to exit by traversing left at the belay to a small dihedral to the top. 
  
 Originally done all trad, the bolts were added for Le Grand Bill. 

Large vertical crack below a dihedral.
Mixed

Version direct de Artéfact en style "off-width" superbe dans le genre. 

La fin est facile mais difficile à protéger. 

Direct version of Artifact superb "off-width" style.

The end is easy but difficult to protect.


Needs at least two #4 and two #5

The first bolted line on the right of Temple solaire. A second pitch is being worked on.

La première ligne équipé à la droite du Temple solaire. Une deuxième longueur est en projet.



On the small ledge in the middle of the cliff, it can be reached using the first pitch of Club Sandwich or on its left Voie d'accès.

Sur la vire au millieu de la paroie, on peux l'ateindre en utilisant la première longueur de Club Sandwich ou la Voie d'accès à gauche.


7 bolts.

climbs.name: Black and White
climbs.fa: Aid 1958, FFA Contrevesy/contreverse: either/soit 1962/63 Jim McCarthy & Claude Lavallée, or 1976 Marc Blais & Normand Cadieux

content.description:
Classic route at Weir. Pitches: (5.9 / 5.10+ / 5.10) The first two pitches can be linked up. Nuts to Camalot #4
Belays are bolted with rap chains.

Crux is on the first pitch, go up the left of the alcove up to the ledge below Temple Solaire head diagonaly right passed large block to the Vire a Bicyclette follow the ledge towards the right end of the cliff, go up the right arete. 5.7/5.4/5.6 Start on the left side of an "A" alcove. Standard rack with a couple larger pieces.
Glue in bolts at the final anchor (belay tree got chopped).

The route was named in reaction to many trees that were cut at the base of the cliff without much reason. "Coupe à blanc" can be translated as "clear cut".

Technical line that begins as "Marie 4 poches", before traversing left. It has a crux on small crimps around 15 meters up the ground and a delicate finish.

This route was put up with questionable ethic since bolts have been added within reaching distance from a well known, travelled and longtime established climb called Marie 4 Poche, a traditionally protected climb. Moreover, this "new" route uses the start of Marie 4 Poche, which has been retro-bolted to allow for a full "sport route".

People had been topropping this line for years, but knew it wasn't reasonable to bolt within a few feets from a classic climb. Apparently the FA party didn't see it that way.

Start on Marie 4 Poche and follow the bolts to the left.
Bolts

Technical and sustained climb. A great finish to Bicentenaire.



5 bolts, single rack #0.2 to #2.

At the grade of A3, this is probably the best aid route in the Laurentians to learn hard aid on. Perfect to prepare yourself for those Yosemite Valley classics (e.g. Zodiac). In June 2020, it was freed and became an interesting test-piece in traditional free climbing. This direct, all-gear, route goes up the steepest and most impressive wall. Please be mindful if you decide to aid it, try to go clean and go easy on the hammer.

I haven't aid it to be honest so I will let others do the detailed description about the aid beta and will only provide beta for free climbing.

Start right of the anchor and climb a short left facing corner (0.1/0.2 BD X4) to a tricky mantle onto a good foot hold to reach the main seam. Place some gear and mantle to a shallow ledge underneath a blank section capped with a few overlaps. Place a bomber finger size cam plus a critical sideway nut a foot above it (#4 BD Stopper) and get ready for the first crux. This next section is a little scary and involves very technical climbing on unusual features. So, battle up this section to a very good hold and place a tiny wire plus a micro cam (0 BD Z4). Mantle onto that good hold to a good left gaston. Place crappy gear in the tiny flake above your head, or not. There is also a good but blindly placed red ballnut in the seam to your right. Now its time for "THE HIGH STEP" which is kind of crux 1.5 and feels like your gonna slip. Do that to reach some thanks god gear placements (0.4-0.5 BD C4) and a good rest right underneath the main crux.

Place a good micro cam in the seam, clip the manky piton nest and go for it using compression moves, sloppy holds, a heel hook and more sloppy holds to finally reach a jug. Reestablish yourself above the crux and place a good cam (0.75 BD C4). Compose yourself and climb an easier section until you reach "THE HEINOUS FINGERLOCK", then climb the roof to a no-hand rest at the horizontal with good gear. Take a few good breath and get ready for the headwall. Climb to the bolt and clip it, or not, then fire the pumpy run out upper section. There are a few available RP's but they are quite strenuous to place.



The route follows a system of seem for its entire length. It starts on the spacious ledge to the right of the Marie 4 Poche/Cordonnier buttress. Start about 40 ft right of the Cordonnier corner. An old 2-bolt anchor and a rusty pin above it marks the start.


The crux section of the route seeps badly during the spring, but it dries and at some point around may/june, it stays dry. Looks like it then stays dry during summer and fall. 


It is quite specific but I would say standard and offset micro cams and nuts, brassies and ballnuts.

Approach route for Vire a Bicyclette ledge. You can stop at the first anchor or top out on the ledge. Below Club Sandwich ledge. Sport
9 Bolts
Full anchors.

climbs.name: L'Épée de Damoclès
climbs.fa: Reequipped by Marche family, 2019; FA Gelu Ionescu, 1990

content.description:
P1 (5.12a) très technique avec un pas de dalle engageant à la fin. La cassure d'une prise de la taille d'un microonde sur la face gauche du pilier à l'automne 2020 rend l'expérience plus soutenue. Ce n'était pas la plus facile de sa cotation et encore moins aujourd'hui. P2 (5.10c) et P3 (5.11c) moins populaires mais le topo le plus récent promet une aventure à ne pas manquer jusqu'au sommet de la falaise. P1 (5.12a) technical with cruxy slab moves up top. A hold breakage the size of a microwave on the left side of the pillar in the fall 2020 leads to a more sustained experience. It was not the easiest of its grade and even less so now. P2 (5.10c) et P3 (5.11c) less popular, but the most recent guidebook promises stellar climbing to the top of the cliff. Sur le pilier, entre Marie 4 poches et Le Cordonnier/Le Monde à l'envers, la ligne de plaquettes évidente.

On the pillar, between Marie 4 poches and Le Cordonnier/Le Monde à l'envers, following the obvious line of bolts. 10 plaquettes (P1), coinceurs + 4 bolts (P2) et11 plaquettes (P3).

10 bolts (P1), gear + 4 bolts (P2) and 11 bolts (P3).

An overhanging hand/fist crack that is mostly the finest trad climb at Weir. To access it, you either have to climb 3D (5.12a) or P1 (5.9) of Black & White (5.10+). If you decide to climb P1 of Black & White, you have to re-establish yourself on a ledge above and left of the anchor. In both cases, I recommend to build a gear belay on the ledge and not using the anchor of 3D, which is kind of too high/uncomfortable. 
  
 Pitch 1: Traverse left and head for the bolt, then clip it. You can also clip a fixed anchor above your head and/or just keep traversing and breaking through the roof (crux). Fight the pump and keep climbing the crack until it ease, right after a wide section. At that point, you can split this pitch by using the anchor that is on your right, or keep climbing and passing through a left facing corner (dirty) to another fixed anchor on La Voie du Centenaire's Ledge. (5.11+) 
  
 Pitch 2: I didn't climb that pitch and it looks dirty. From the anchor you have to go right and climb some overhanging dihedral. (5.8)

This climb is located in Black & White's area. You either have to climb 3D (5.12a) or the first pitch of Black & White to access it. Refer to the description above for details.
to Camalot #3. Doubles of hand size pieces are useful.

A hard and unprotected start leads to a thin crack. Reach up to a positive pedestal and with delicate footwork mantle onto it. Unprotected and quite high. After that the route is well protected. At the ledge place a couple solid pieces to protect the second and traverse right to a bolted belay.

This is also the direct start to the variantion of Cordonnier 11+



About 4 meter right of Apportez Votre Vin. Look for a thin crack about 3 meters above the ground.

0.2 to #1 BDs

Petite ligne technique pas évidente à déchiffrer. 



Départ à Gauche de la cheminée ou niveau de la craque qui vas vers la droite.

plaquettes

Pitch 1, 5.10- 
 Head up the large crack system with delicate feet (v1) all the way up to the ledge. 
  
 Pitch 2, 5.10+ 
 Climb the dihedral to the roof (v2). Continue in the dihedral until you can traverse right on slopping rails and undercling flakes, then head back left in a horizontal crack to the belay. 
  
 Pitch 3, 5.11- 
 Head straight up from the belay, traverse right at the bolt to gain a dihedral and head more or less straight up to the top. 
  
 Variation 1, before you reach the first belay, you can traverse right to the anchor of Apportez votre vin for a single rope rap. 
  
 Variation 2, traverse right to Variante du cordonnier 5.11+

Full rack, micro cams to #3

Trad climbing to start, then transitions to overhanging sport

Left of Apportez votre vin
Standard rack

45 meters of splendid climbing on a beautiful vertical wall. Very nice movement. 2 cruxes on crimps that you have to hold tight. Bolts are a little spaced but the falls are clean. Just focus on climbing!

45 mètres de "conti" sur un superbe mur vertical très imposant. La gestuelle est magnifique, et les passages clés se jouent sur des petites réglettes qu'il faut savoir tenir fort! Les plaquettes sont assez espacées, mais les chutes ne sont pas dangereuses.



Starts in the middle of the "Vire du Temple" ledge at the bottom right of a detached flake.

Débute au milieu de la Vire du Temple à la base droite du feuillet détaché.


17 bolts. From the top, the easiest option is to lower to the anchors of 5km, pull the rope and lower again from there.

17 plaquettes. Du sommet, la meilleure option est de descendre au relai de 5km, tirer la corde et se faire descendre de nouveau depuis là.

This is a fun multipitch adventure. 

This route has 2 sports pitches followed by a mixed third one. 

P1 : Start with hard moves that lead to stances and then do a hard sequence (crux) to reestablish yourself on the slab. Traverse and climb the dihedral to the anchor. (5.11+)

P2 : I am not sure if you should stay to the right of the first bolt or not, well my partner went left of it and I stayed right. In both case, it felt hard 5.10. After two bolts gain a ledge and traverse right to a high bolt, clip it and climb trending left to another bolt then straight to the anchor (5.10++)

P3 : Haven't climb it as we forgot to bring cams... but it looked good. (5.12 -)

Descend : Rappel the route!

Second bolted line to the right of Black and White
Bolts for P1 and P2. A few cams for P3.

Variante de Romania.
Départ quelques mètres à droite de cette dernière. Après une dizaine de mouvements on rejoint Romania pour une dizaine de mètres. Gestuelle fluide dans de bonnes prises, la paroi devenant progressivement plus raide.
Aux alentours du 2/3 de la voie, il faut traverser sur la droite pour atteindre une bonne prise verticale. C'est la dernière du genre. Profitez en pour prendre un dernier repos, lancer un regard d'adieu à vos empreintes digitales puis lancez vous dans le crux. Ce dernier constiste en une succession de mouvements "blocs" sur de tout petits grattons combinés à des pieds précaires... courage! 

Variant of Romania.
Starts a couple meters to the right of Romania. Nice movement on a progressively steepening wall. At around 2/3 of the route, traverse to the right to a good hold. The last of its kind. Shake out a little bit, breathe, say farewell to your skin and start the crux. Expect some painfully tiny crimps and technical feet placements. 

Right of Romania
Bolts

Pitch 1, 5.10+  25m 
 Left facing dihedral. Small-medium caming units and nuts. 
  
 Pitch 2, 5.8 
 Follow the left dihedral of the two visible.  Belay on the right on the pillar. 
  
 Pitch 3, 5.11- 
 Start right off the belay, traverse right at the bolt, head up a small dihedral.  Then traverse again towards the right to a large left facing dihedral under the summit.

Nuts to BD C4 #3.

An amazing route that feature an airy traverse.

P1. Start to the left of a lower roof and follow some bolts to a thin ledge. Keep going straight to gain the big ledge. There is a bolted belay behind the giant boulder. (5.11-)

P2. Step on top of the giant boulder and make a move to gain the crack and bolts. Gain a ledge and start the airy traverse to the left. Follow the sloppy ledge clipping more bolts until you get to a bigger ledge with a bolted belay. (5.11-)

P3. Go straight up. (5.10+)

Descent : Rap with one rope or walk off.



This line is located to the right of the Black and white sector. About 20-30m from the chimney. There are 3 lines of bolts. This line uses the bolt on the left.

Single from 0.3 to 2, nuts

Reported as one of the hardest trad route in the Laurentians, this route has seen only very few ascents. You have to either climb 3D (5.12a) or climb P1 (5.9+) of Black & White (5.10+). Build an anchor on a nice ledge after traversing left from the anchor of B&W's P1. Face climb trending left from the ledge to a bolt then to an anchor that you can also clip. Get to the horizontal crack just underneath the roof. Traverse right to a good hold and climb the roof with some powerful sequences on the exit. Keep going straight to some thin crack to a face finish. You have to either climb 3D (5.12a) or climb P1 (5.9) of Black & White (5.10+). To Camalot #2, with doubles from #0.3 to #0.75 plus nuts. There's a bolted anchor a the top of the pitch.

Descent: Rappel with a 70m rope. I know you can get down with a 60m but it barely is long enough.

Start right of Black & White, at a high bolt (Stick clip). 
  
 P1 (5.11a/b):  Climb underneath the first bolt and reestablish yourself left of the second bolt in a small left-facing dihedral, on a sloppy ledge. Clip the second bolt and traverse right, gain another bolt then a good rest. Continue on small holds to some good crimps and feet. Crank throught the overhang using the arete and reestablish yourself to the right at a two-bolt anchor. (20 m) 
  
 P2 & P3 (5.11c & 5.11b): I haven't climb them yet.

Quickdraws only!

One of the nice route of the site, the original start is in the ramp (on the left) with a rather high bolt but a direct start has been added (stick clip recommended) once you pass the mantle, the face is just awesome to climb. Exit to the left (crux) to go into the dihedral or continue climbing on the ridge. The rating doesn't change no matter which version you choose.

Une des belle voie de la place, le départ original est dans la rampe (à gauche) avec une plaquette assez haute mais un départ direct a été ajouté (stick clip recommandé) rendu au rétablissement, la face est juste superbe à grimper. Sortir à gauche (crux)  pour aller dans le dièdre ou continuer à grimper sur l’arrête. La cote ne change pas peu importe la version choisie.


Bolts

The only sport route to reach the small ledge where multiple routes start from like Temple du soleil.



in the middle of the wall section, it lines up near 5Km.

4 bolts, anchors are provided on the ledge.

Right end of the cliff, Most of the area was mostly aid routes but as time went by many of those routes went free and new lines came to life pushing the limits of the sport. 
  
 Be careful of falling ice early in the season! 
  
 The upper right section of this cliff holds a series of hard routes and projects which begin on the Vire a Bicyclette, a small ledge accessible by Club sandwich and a few routes right of there. 
  
 Sections Left to Right: 
 Mur de l'Ouest 
 Mur du Capitaine 
 Ligne Jaune - 10'000 Zoulous 
 Adagio 
 Black and White - Club Sandwich 
 Vire a Bicyclette Upper right section of Club Sandwich
